definition_brief: Major artery supplying blood to upper limb, originating from brachiocephalic trunk (right) or aortic arch (left)
description_full: The subclavian artery extends from the aortic arch (left) or brachiocephalic trunk (right) to the lateral border of the first rib, where it becomes the axillary artery. It arches over the cervical pleura and lung apex, passing between the anterior and middle scalene muscles. The artery is divided into three parts by the anterior scalene: first part (medial), second part (posterior), and third part (lateral). Major branches include the vertebral, internal thoracic, thyrocervical trunk, costocervical trunk, and sometimes the dorsal scapular artery.
clinical_significance: **Subclavian steal syndrome** causes reversal of vertebral artery flow due to proximal subclavian stenosis. **Thoracic outlet syndrome** can compress the artery. **Subclavian artery aneurysm** is rare but potentially life-threatening. **Cervical rib** may compress the artery. The artery is at risk during **clavicle fractures** and **first rib resection**. **Subclavian vein catheterization** risks arterial puncture. **Atherosclerosis** commonly affects the left subclavian origin.

definition_brief: Continuation of subclavian artery extending from first rib to inferior border of teres major, supplying shoulder and arm
description_full: The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery, extending from the lateral border of the first rib to the inferior border of teres major, where it becomes the brachial artery. It is divided into three parts by pectoralis minor: first part (medial, 1 branch), second part (posterior, 2 branches), and third part (lateral, 3 branches). The artery is surrounded by the cords of the brachial plexus and accompanied by the axillary vein. Major branches supply the shoulder region, chest wall, and scapular area.
clinical_significance: **Axillary artery injury** can occur with anterior shoulder dislocation, especially in elderly patients. **Thrombosis** may result from thoracic outlet syndrome or repetitive trauma (e.g., baseball pitchers). **Aneurysm** is rare but more common in patients using crutches. The artery is at risk during **axillary lymph node dissection** and **shoulder surgery**. **Axillary artery occlusion** can cause acute limb ischemia. **Compartment syndrome** may result from arterial injury.
origin: Continuation of subclavian artery at lateral border of first rib

definition_brief: Main artery of arm extending from teres major to cubital fossa where it bifurcates into radial and ulnar arteries
description_full: The brachial artery is the continuation of the axillary artery, beginning at the inferior border of teres major and descending along the medial aspect of the arm. It runs superficial to brachialis muscle and is accompanied by the median nerve (which crosses it anteriorly mid-arm) and basilic vein. The artery is relatively superficial and easily palpable throughout its course. At the cubital fossa, approximately 1 cm distal to the elbow crease, it divides into radial and ulnar arteries. Major branches include deep brachial (profunda brachii), superior and inferior ulnar collateral arteries, and muscular branches.
clinical_significance: The brachial artery is the **standard site for blood pressure measurement** using a sphygmomanometer. **Brachial artery injury** can occur with supracondylar humeral fractures in children, requiring urgent evaluation for **compartment syndrome**. **Median nerve** injury may accompany arterial trauma. The artery is accessed for **cardiac catheterization** and **arterial blood gas sampling**. **Brachial artery thrombosis** causes acute limb ischemia. **Volkmann's ischemic contracture** results from prolonged ischemia.
origin: Continuation of axillary artery at inferior border of teres major

definition_brief: Lateral terminal branch of brachial artery supplying lateral forearm and hand, commonly used for pulse assessment
description_full: The radial artery is the smaller of the two terminal branches of the brachial artery, arising in the cubital fossa. It descends along the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm between brachioradialis and flexor carpi radialis, becoming increasingly superficial distally. At the wrist, it is easily palpable lateral to the FCR tendon and is the standard site for pulse assessment. The artery curves dorsally around the radial styloid through the anatomical snuffbox, then passes between the two heads of the first dorsal interosseous muscle to enter the palm, where it forms the deep palmar arch.
clinical_significance: The radial artery is the **most common site for pulse palpation** and **arterial blood gas sampling**. **Allen's test** assesses adequacy of ulnar artery collateral flow before radial artery cannulation or harvesting. **Radial artery catheterization** is used for invasive blood pressure monitoring. The artery is the **preferred conduit for coronary artery bypass grafting** (CABG). **Radial artery thrombosis** can occur post-catheterization. **Pseudoaneurysm** may develop after arterial puncture.
origin: Lateral terminal branch of brachial artery in cubital fossa

definition_brief: Larger terminal branch of brachial artery supplying medial forearm and forming superficial palmar arch
description_full: The ulnar artery is the larger of the two terminal branches of the brachial artery, arising in the cubital fossa. It initially descends deep to the pronator teres and flexor digitorum superficialis, then emerges to run along the medial aspect of the forearm between FCU and FDP. The ulnar nerve lies medial to the artery in the distal two-thirds of the forearm. The common interosseous artery is an early major branch. At the wrist, the artery passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum through Guyon's canal, lateral to the pisiform, and forms the superficial palmar arch in the hand.
clinical_significance: **Ulnar artery thrombosis** (hypothenar hammer syndrome) results from repetitive trauma to the hypothenar eminence. **Allen's test** evaluates ulnar artery patency before radial artery procedures. **Ulnar artery aneurysm** or pseudoaneurysm can occur in Guyon's canal. The artery may be injured during **forearm fractures** or **compartment syndrome fasciotomy**. **Congenital absence** or hypoplasia increases reliance on radial artery. **Duplex ultrasound** assesses flow and patency.
origin: Medial terminal branch of brachial artery in cubital fossa

definition_brief: Largest branch of brachial artery accompanying radial nerve through radial groove, supplying triceps and posterior arm
description_full: The deep brachial artery (profunda brachii) is the largest branch of the brachial artery, arising near the inferior border of teres major. It accompanies the radial nerve posteriorly, passing through the triangular interval (between teres major, long head of triceps, and humerus) and spiraling around the humerus in the radial groove between medial and lateral heads of triceps. The artery supplies the triceps muscle and posterior arm, and contributes to collateral circulation around the elbow via radial and middle collateral branches.
clinical_significance: **Deep brachial artery injury** often accompanies **mid-shaft humeral fractures** and **radial nerve injury** due to their close anatomical relationship in the radial groove. **Pseudoaneurysm** can develop post-trauma. The artery is important in **collateral circulation** around the elbow, which may maintain forearm perfusion even with brachial artery occlusion. **Variant anatomy** is common. The artery may be injured during **humeral nailing** or **plating** procedures.
origin: Branch of brachial artery near inferior border of teres major

definition_brief: Branch of common interosseous artery descending on anterior surface of interosseous membrane, supplying deep forearm flexors
description_full: The anterior interosseous artery arises from the common interosseous artery (a branch of the ulnar artery) shortly after the latter's origin. It descends along the anterior surface of the interosseous membrane between FDP and FPL, accompanied by the anterior interosseous nerve. The artery supplies the deep flexor muscles, radius, ulna, and interosseous membrane. Distally, it pierces the interosseous membrane to anastomose with the posterior interosseous artery and contributes to the dorsal carpal arch.
clinical_significance: The anterior interosseous artery forms important **collateral circulation** with the posterior interosseous artery. **Persistent median artery** (embryological remnant) may accompany this vessel and contribute to **carpal tunnel syndrome** if enlarged. The artery may be injured during **forearm fractures** or **deep flexor tendon surgery**. **Compartment syndrome** can compromise arterial flow. The vessel is encountered during **anterior surgical approaches** to the forearm.
origin: Branch of common interosseous artery (from ulnar artery)

definition_brief: Branch of common interosseous artery passing posteriorly to descend between superficial and deep forearm extensors
description_full: The posterior interosseous artery arises from the common interosseous artery and passes posteriorly between the radius and ulna, above the proximal edge of the interosseous membrane. It descends in the posterior compartment of the forearm between the superficial and deep layers of extensor muscles, accompanied by the posterior interosseous nerve. The artery supplies the extensor muscles and contributes to anastomoses around the elbow and wrist. It terminates by anastomosing with the anterior interosseous artery.
clinical_significance: The posterior interosseous artery provides important **collateral circulation** for the forearm. **Posterior interosseous artery flap** is used in reconstructive hand surgery. The artery may be injured during **posterior forearm approaches**, **radial head excision**, or **Monteggia fracture-dislocations**. **Compartment syndrome** can compromise flow. The artery forms part of the **recurrent interosseous artery** contributing to elbow collateral circulation.
origin: Branch of common interosseous artery (from ulnar artery), passes posteriorly above interosseous membrane

definition_brief: Arterial arch in palm formed primarily by ulnar artery with contribution from radial artery, supplying digits
description_full: The superficial palmar arch is formed predominantly by the terminal branch of the ulnar artery with a contribution from the superficial palmar branch of the radial artery (when present) or the princeps pollicis artery. The arch lies immediately deep to the palmar aponeurosis and superficial to the flexor tendons and lumbricals. It gives rise to three common palmar digital arteries, which divide into proper palmar digital arteries supplying adjacent sides of the medial four digits. The arch is complete in approximately 80% of individuals.
clinical_significance: **Incomplete superficial palmar arch** occurs in ~20% of people and may increase risk of digital ischemia. **Allen's test** assesses arch patency before radial artery procedures. **Palmar arch thrombosis** can occur with trauma or thrombophilia. The arch may be injured during **Dupuytren's contracture surgery** or **carpal tunnel release**. **Aneurysm** is rare but can occur with trauma. **Ulnar artery dominance** of the arch is most common (80%).
origin: Primarily continuation of ulnar artery with variable contribution from radial artery

definition_brief: Arterial arch in palm formed primarily by radial artery with contribution from ulnar artery, lying deep to flexor tendons
description_full: The deep palmar arch is formed predominantly by the terminal branch of the radial artery (after it passes through the first dorsal interosseous muscle) with a contribution from the deep palmar branch of the ulnar artery. The arch lies on the metacarpal bases and interosseous muscles, deep to the flexor tendons and the superficial palmar arch. It gives rise to palmar metacarpal arteries and the princeps pollicis artery. The arch is complete in approximately 98% of individuals and lies about 1 cm proximal to the superficial arch.
clinical_significance: The deep palmar arch is **nearly always complete** (98%), providing important collateral circulation. **Deep arch injury** is less common than superficial arch injury due to its protected position. The arch may be injured during **deep hand lacerations** or **metacarpal fractures**. **Thrombosis** is rare. The arch is the main source of **princeps pollicis artery** (supplies thumb). **Anatomical variation** is less common than in superficial arch.
origin: Primarily continuation of radial artery with contribution from deep branch of ulnar artery

definition_brief: Large superficial vein of upper limb ascending along lateral aspect of arm to drain into axillary vein
description_full: The cephalic vein originates from the dorsal venous network of the hand on the radial side. It ascends along the lateral aspect of the forearm and arm, becoming more anterior as it ascends. In the forearm, it runs along the lateral border. In the arm, it ascends in the groove between deltoid and pectoralis major (deltopectoral groove). It pierces the clavipectoral fascia and terminates by draining into the axillary vein just below the clavicle. The vein is typically connected to the basilic vein by the median cubital vein at the elbow.
clinical_significance: The cephalic vein is commonly used for **venipuncture** and **IV catheter placement**. **Arteriovenous fistula** for hemodialysis often uses the cephalic vein. **Thrombophlebitis** can occur with IV catheters. The vein is used as a **conduit for coronary artery bypass**. **Cephalic vein cutdown** provides vascular access. The vein may be injured during **shoulder surgery**. **Compression** can occur in thoracic outlet syndrome.
origin: Dorsal venous network of hand (radial side)

definition_brief: Large superficial vein ascending along medial arm, becoming axillary vein at inferior border of teres major
description_full: The basilic vein originates from the dorsal venous network of the hand on the ulnar side and the palmar venous network. It ascends along the medial aspect of the forearm and arm. At the mid-arm, it pierces the deep fascia to run alongside the brachial artery. At the inferior border of teres major, it joins the brachial veins to form the axillary vein. The basilic vein receives the median cubital vein at the elbow and is typically larger than the cephalic vein.
clinical_significance: The basilic vein is a **preferred site for venipuncture** when visible, being typically larger than cephalic vein. **Basilic vein transposition** creates arteriovenous fistulas for hemodialysis when cephalic vein is inadequate. **Thrombophlebitis** is common. The vein's deep course in the upper arm places it near the **medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve** and **ulnar nerve**, risking injury during procedures. The vein may be used as a **bypass conduit**.
origin: Dorsal and palmar venous networks of hand (ulnar side)

definition_brief: Superficial vein connecting cephalic and basilic veins in cubital fossa, most common site for venipuncture
description_full: The median cubital vein is a superficial vein that crosses the cubital fossa obliquely, connecting the cephalic vein laterally to the basilic vein medially. It typically lies anterior to the bicipital aponeurosis, which separates it from the brachial artery and median nerve. The vein is highly variable in size and course. It receives tributaries from the deep veins via the deep median cubital vein (perforating vein). The median cubital vein is the most commonly used vein for venipuncture due to its size, superficial location, and relative immobility.
clinical_significance: The median cubital vein is the **preferred site for venipuncture** (phlebotomy, IV access, blood donation) due to its large size and stable position. The **bicipital aponeurosis** protects the underlying brachial artery and median nerve from needle injury. **Anatomical variation** is common (~30% of people). **Iatrogenic nerve injury** can occur if the needle penetrates too deeply. **Hematoma formation** is the most common complication. The vein may be **absent** in some individuals.
origin: Variable; typically arises from cephalic vein or deep veins

definition_brief: Large vein draining upper limb, extending from teres major to first rib where it becomes subclavian vein
description_full: The axillary vein is formed by the union of the brachial veins and basilic vein at the inferior border of teres major. It ascends medial to the axillary artery through the axilla and becomes the subclavian vein at the lateral border of the first rib. The vein receives tributaries corresponding to branches of the axillary artery, plus the cephalic vein. It lies anterior and medial to the axillary artery and is surrounded by the axillary lymph nodes. The vein lacks valves in its proximal portion.
clinical_significance: **Axillary vein thrombosis** (Paget-Schroetter syndrome or effort thrombosis) occurs in athletes and causes arm swelling. **Thoracic outlet syndrome** can cause venous compression. **Central venous catheterization** via the axillary approach is safer than subclavian but technically more difficult. **Axillary lymph node dissection** risks vein injury. **Air embolism** is a risk during catheter insertion due to negative intrathoracic pressure. The vein may be injured during **shoulder surgery**.
origin: Union of brachial veins and basilic vein at inferior border of teres major

definition_brief: Large vein continuing from axillary vein at first rib to join internal jugular vein forming brachiocephalic vein
description_full: The subclavian vein is the continuation of the axillary vein, beginning at the lateral border of the first rib. It passes anterior to the anterior scalene muscle (unlike the subclavian artery, which passes posterior) and beneath the clavicle. The vein arches over the first rib and receives the external jugular vein before joining the internal jugular vein posterior to the sternoclavicular joint to form the brachiocephalic vein. On the left side, it also receives the thoracic duct; on the right, the right lymphatic duct. The vein contains a valve at its junction with the internal jugular vein.
clinical_significance: The subclavian vein is a common site for **central venous catheterization** for hemodialysis, chemotherapy, and hemodynamic monitoring. **Pneumothorax** is a significant risk during cannulation. **Thoracic outlet syndrome** can cause vein compression and thrombosis. **Subclavian vein thrombosis** causes arm swelling and requires anticoagulation. **Clavicle fractures** may injure the vein. **Superior vena cava syndrome** can extend to involve the subclavian veins. **Pacemaker leads** commonly traverse this vein.
origin: Continuation of axillary vein at lateral border of first rib
